item.title: Removing chlorophyll from leaves
item.description: It's actually possible to remove the chlorophyll from leaves pretty easily.

media:content.media:title: Removing chlorophyll from leaves
media:content.media:description: It's actually possible to remove the chlorophyll from leaves pretty easily.

item.title: Drawing on water
item.description: You can make your drawings animated by moving the water. It looks so surreal to watch a stick man become animated in real life. This is a new take on the dry erase marker stick figure trick. I talk about what is happening to make the dry erase marker ink float on top of the water to make these animations come to life.

item.title: Marshmallows getting their soul sucked out
item.description: I put 30 marshmallows in a vacuum chamber

item.title: This is the scariest sound in the world
item.description: The sound often called the "scariest in the world" is produced by the Aztec death whistle, an ancient instrument that creates a terrifying, human-like scream by matching the frequency of fearful human screams

item.title: Real-life Nether Portal
item.description: In this video, I show you how I made a circular Jacob's Ladder using a magnet and high voltage

item.title: Neutron star physics
item.description: In this video I show you what happens when you try to get close to 1 drop of a neutron star. I tell you how a neutron star is made and then also talk about different types of stars and show you a method that you could use to actually get very close to a small drop of a neutron star!

item.title: Can you see haidinger's brush?
item.description: This video shows how to see Haidinger's brush and what it looks like:

item.title: How does the chain fountain work?
item.description: The amazing self-siphoning chain fountain actually works. Then I show you a chain that can actually get sucked down when you drop it on a table! This is an amazing physics demonstration that was only recently discovered and finally modeled. This is similar to the molecular version of this event with the self pouring self siphoning fluid polyethylene glycol. Here is a link to the published papers on this phenomenon.

item.title: Making a sound lens
item.description: Making a sound lens involves using a balloon filled with a gas denser than air, like carbon dioxide to bend sound waves and focus them, similar to how a glass lens bends light, making sound louder at a focal point.

item.title: Turn anything into a speaker
item.description: In this video I show you how a vibration speaker works to amplify sound. And then I put it in my vacuum chamber to finalize the idea that sound cannot propagate in a vacuum.

item.title: A metal heart-beating
item.description: In this video I show you how to make a gallium beating heart. I show you the reaction that happens when you add gallium to sulfuric acid and then touch iron to the beaded up gallium. It causes a pulsing action due to the surface of the gallium reacting with the sulfuric acid and then reversing once it touches the iron.

item.title: Breaking a diamond with a hammer ��​��
item.description: Breaking a diamond with a hammer ��​�� #experiment #physics #breaking #diamond #science #reels

item.title: Why doesn’t lightning take the shortest path?
item.description: A clear science explanation breaks down how lightning forms and why it branches through the air instead of traveling in a straight line to the ground.

item.title: Throwing a -346°F snowball made of solid nitrogen
item.description: A dramatic experiment shows what happens when a snowball made from solid nitrogen is thrown, revealing extreme cold effects and the unusual physics of materials at cryogenic temperatures.

item.title: Opening liquid nitrogen under water
item.description: A science experiment opens a container of liquid nitrogen under water, revealing dramatic bubbling and rapid gas expansion while explaining the physics behind the reaction.

item.title: This Cloaking Device Actually Works!
item.description: A science test demonstrates a real cloaking effect, showing how the device bends light to hide an object and explaining the physics behind the illusion.

item.title: Easy way to separate alcohol and water
item.description: A science demonstration explores how alcohol and water can be separated, explaining the basic principles behind the process and why it works.

item.title: The amazing behavior of self-assembling wires
item.description: An experiment shows wires moving and assembling on their own, revealing how magnetism, current, and physical forces can create unexpectedly organized patterns.

item.title: The weird physics of red-hot mirrors
item.description: Heating a mirror to glowing red raises surprising questions about reflection and light, and this experiment explains what changes when a mirror gets extremely hot.

item.title: Painting a whole room with the world's blackest paint
item.description: A dramatic experiment transforms an entire room using ultra-black paint, showing how it absorbs light and changes depth perception in a way that looks almost unreal.
